domains.name: Information Processing
domains.description: How you prefer to receive and process new information

questions.question: When learning about a new concept in class, you prefer:

options.text: Seeing diagrams, charts, or visual representations of the concept
Listening to the teacher explain it and discussing it with others
Reading detailed notes or textbook explanations about it
Trying hands-on examples or experiments to understand it
You can picture it in your mind with images or mental maps
You've heard it explained or discussed it out loud
You've written it down in your own words or taken detailed notes
You've practiced it or applied it in a real situation

questions.question: When encountering complex information, you find it easier to understand through:

options.text: Flowcharts, infographics, or video demonstrations
Podcasts, lectures, or verbal explanations
Articles, books, or written step-by-step instructions
Interactive simulations, labs, or real-world practice

domains.name: Problem Solving
domains.description: How you approach solving difficult problems

questions.question: When faced with a challenging problem, your first instinct is to:

options.text: Draw it out or create a visual model of the problem
Talk it through with someone or explain it aloud to yourself
Write out the problem and list possible solutions
Try different approaches hands-on until something works

questions.question: You verify your understanding of a solution by:

options.text: Looking at examples and comparing patterns visually
Discussing your reasoning and getting verbal feedback
Writing out your logic step-by-step to check for errors
Testing it in practice to see if it actually works

questions.question: When learning a new procedure or process, you prefer to:

options.text: Watch a demonstration or see a visual guide
Have someone walk you through it verbally
Read the instructions carefully before starting
Jump in and figure it out by doing it yourself

domains.name: Collaboration & Communication
domains.description: How you work and communicate with others

questions.question: When explaining a concept to someone else, you naturally:

options.text: Draw diagrams or show them visual examples
Explain it verbally with detailed descriptions
Write it out or share written resources with them
Demonstrate it through actions or examples they can try

questions.question: In group projects, you contribute best by:

options.text: Creating visual presentations, designs, or diagrams
Leading discussions and brainstorming sessions
Researching and writing reports or documentation
Building prototypes or doing hands-on implementation work

questions.question: You prefer to receive feedback through:

options.text: Highlighted documents or visual annotations
One-on-one conversations or voice notes
Written comments or detailed written critiques
Guided practice sessions where you can improve by doing

domains.name: Study & Review
domains.description: How you prepare for assessments and review material

questions.question: When studying for an exam, you find it most helpful to:

options.text: Create mind maps, color-coded notes, or study graphics
Record yourself or listen to study materials/discussions
Rewrite notes, make outlines, and read through materials multiple times
Practice problems, create flashcards, and quiz yourself actively

questions.question: You organize your study materials by:

options.text: Using color coding, visual folders, or diagram-based systems
Recording notes by topic to listen back to later
Creating detailed written indexes or organized note documents
Grouping by practice exercises or hands-on activities

questions.question: Before a test, you review most effectively by:

options.text: Looking over visual summaries, charts, and highlighted materials
Discussing the material with study partners or teaching it aloud
Re-reading your notes and creating summary sheets
Working through practice problems and sample questions

domains.name: Application & Practice
domains.description: How you apply knowledge and practice skills

questions.question: When learning a new skill, you master it best by:

options.text: Watching tutorials and observing skilled demonstrations
Having someone coach you through it with verbal guidance
Following written guides and studying technique descriptions
Practicing repeatedly through trial and error
Creating visual summaries or concept maps to see connections
Explaining concepts out loud or teaching them to someone
Writing practice essays or answering written questions
Applying concepts in real scenarios or simulations

questions.question: When facing a practical task you haven't done before, you prefer to:

options.text: Look at pictures or diagrams of the finished result first
Ask someone to explain the approach and key considerations
Read about best practices and study written instructions
Start working on it and learn by making mistakes
